Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility. LPA met with facility supervisor Araceli Iniguez-Reyes. There were eight staff and nine clients present at the facility during this inspection. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received information concerning potential safety hazards. LPA observed three different houses of different addresses on the 85-acre lot/premise. There were no dogs roaming the property at this time. However, staff reported that there are two small dogs and one medium size dog that are friendly and belong to one of the other property occupants. LPA also observed several exposed wires that are part of another property on the premise. It appeared that there were new electrical wires put in and the old wires were exposed. The facility was advised to reach out to maintenance to have the old wires removed as soon as possible. The facility will notify CCL once the exposed wires are removed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Araceli Iniguez-Reyes.

Staff and client files were sent to LPA Raissi by Cheryl Rouse prior to this visit. 1. The facility and grounds are in good repair, free of mess, and free of obstructions. 2. There is adequate indoor activity space and materials. 3. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds are in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 8. The facility is a two-story building that includes: ten (10) bedrooms upstairs; four (4) bathrooms upstairs; laundry room upstairs; living room upstairs; game room upstairs; staff office upstairs; snack room upstairs; and, kitchen, dining, and game room downstairs. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Carbon monoxide detector observed. 16. Fire extinguishers properly charged. 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 18. Facility maintains a current fire certificate. 19. Evidence for the allegation "Facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for a resident", as follows: On 6/14/2021 at 9: PM C1 was in a fight with another resident at the facility, Client 2 (C2) DOB: 1/28/2005. There was a video of the fight. Based on observations of the video by this LPA, C1 pushed resident, C2. C2 then punched C1 in his face several times, and the staff stood watching C1 get hurt. Staff reached their arm out then drew it back. The residents were chanting hit him harder! drop him on the floor! teach him a lesson! Then staff yelled, the cops were called. The other residents at the facility video typed the fight and posted it on social media: Snap Chat and Instagram. Shortly after the fight, C1 was taken to the emergency. C1 had sustained injuries, which include a broken nose, a cut behind his ear, and his arm was hurt. Based on interviews with staff members it was known that C1 and C2 are associated to an opposing gang, C2 is associated with blue (Sureno gang) and C1 is associated with red (Norteno gang). Interviews with PO and CSW confirmed that C1 is associated with red (Norteno gang). The Program Description states, "Examples of when a youth may be screened out may include a youth who is a sexual perpetrator if there is a victim(s) already in placement that would potentially be put at risk or an entrenched gang member who is in an opposing gang of a youth already in placement...Having two Safety Net Shelter locations allows flexibility to make the most appropriate placement match" (PD, Page 13). Based on interviews with staff members, moments before the fight, three (3) residents and the aggressor (C2) were making gang gestures in order to intimidate C1. The Program Description states, "NO GANG ACTIVITY. Any gang related activity, including throwing gang signs, wearing gang related clothing, or having gang related conversation, is unacceptable. Tagging of any kind is NOT allowed in the program" (PD, Page 25). A review of the staff schedule (Crisis Residential Staff Schedule: Week June 13, 2021- June 19, 2021) obtained from the agency administrator revealed that there were supposed to be three (3) staff members on shift. During the time of the incident there were only two (2) staff members for eleven (11) clients. Interviews with staff members confirmed that there is supposed to be three (3) staff members during the night shift and that there were only two (2) staff members during the time of the incident. Furthermore, the Program Description states, "Clients identified as high risk for behavior issues receive additional monitoring from program staff, which increase the client to staff ratio" (PD, Page 36). Investigation interviews, and a review of documents, which include the Program Description and Staff Schedules prove that the agency did not provide adequate supervision for the clients in care and did not follow the Program Description by screening out opposing gang members and increasing the client to staff ratio in order to provide additional monitoring. Therefore, the compliant is Substantiated. Based on LPA Raissi's observations, records reviewed, and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation, "Facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for a resident" is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Deficiencies (Type A) were cited. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Cheryl Rouse, whose signature acknowledges receipt.

narrative: Attendees of the facility: Cheryl Rouse, Eva Haile CCL: Helga Wong and Carolyn Flynn - Licensing Program Manager, Selena Hood and Vaishali Singh-Soon Licensing Program Analyst Discussion: - Current substantiated complaint received on 6/29/21 re facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for a client. Two clients from different gangs physically fought in the facility resulting a client being punch multiple times in the head and sustained bleeding and a fracture nose in the facility. - Facility did not following their program statement/plan related to gang activities and affiliation -Facility did not follow their program plan on assaultive behavior to control of environment, removing other youth from situation, lowering lights and volume to reduce stimuli, maintaining safe distance from youth while using calming, verbal skills to de-escalate. -Staffing Facility will do the following and submit them to Licensing Office by December 31, 2021: - Lic 500 form on current staff schedule to ensure the facility have adequate staffing to meet the needs of the clients - Update facility program plan to ensure staff response and take action on assaultive behavior and address gang activities and affiliation - Training and Plan on de-escalation and intervention on client behaviors The Department informed facility representatives today that this complaint/incident will be refer to the Legal Division for ECP.

On June 21, 2022 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood met with Cheryl Rouse, Administrator, in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) regarding a substantiated incident. On 09/30/2021, the department concluded an investigation into the allegations that facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for a resident which resulted in C1 (see LIC811 - Confidential Names List dated July 7, 2021) sustaining a broken nose, scratches behind their ears, and a hurt arm. The allegations were found to be substantiated and the facility was cited per ILS, Personal Rights (a)(b)(1). Per confidential interviews, Bill Wilson Center staff were aware that C1 and C2 were associated with opposing gangs. Per staffing records, the facility was understaffed the evening of the incident.The department has concluded an analysis and has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for the serious bodily injury. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(c), the Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00 on today's date, June 21, 2022. Continued on LIC809C... The above information was reviewed during the meeting and appeal rights were provided. A copy of this report, the LIC811-Confidential Names List, Civil Penalty Assessment, and Appeal Rights were sent to Administrator, Cheryl Rouse, who agreed to sign the report and email it back to LPA Singh-Sood. Email was sent with a read receipt notification.

Continued... The report detailed that while C1 was placed at the facility, C1 disclosed an incident in which another minor entered C1's room and hit C1. The report included that on September 18, 2024, C1 absconded from the facility after notifying staff that C1 would be going to wash their clothing at a laundromat, despite the facility having a washer and dryer onsite. Additionally, the report detailed that C1 was not currently enrolled in or actively attending school. During the investigation, LPA Saeteurn interviewed clients (C1-C5), Staff (S1- S5), Witnesses (W1-W4) and reviewed pertinent facility records. In response to the allegation that staff did not prevent physical altercation between children, confidential interviews did not reveal any physical altercations between C1 and any other resident. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was a client that enjoyed participating in multiple activities, was engaged in services, and was described as being friendly with staff and peers. Confidential interviews did, however, share that early into C1's arrival at the facility there were some situations in which C1 and C2 engaged in exchanging looks and made comments to one another during group activities, but interviews did not reveal that any physical altercations occurred. Confidential interviews revealed that there were situations in which some clients went into C1's room to take things. Confidential interview indicated that the clients were redirected and reminded by staff that they are not allowed in other clients' rooms; however, none of the incidents resulted in a physical altercation. A review of Special Incident Reports sent to CCL from the facility did not reveal any reports of a physical altercation occurring. In response to the allegation that staff did not supervise minor resulting in the minor being absent without leave from the facility, confidential interviews revealed that on the evening of September 18, 2024, C1 requested to wash their clothes. Confidential interviews revealed that during that time, staff were attempting to deescalate a client in care. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 entered the laundry room and staff were able to hear C1 starting their laundry while the door was open. A conflicting confidential interview revealed that the laundry room door leading to the inside of the home was closed which prompted staff to check in on C1. Confidential interviews revealed that S5 noticed that C1 was not in the laundry room and immediately began the facility's unauthorized leave protocol. Continued... Continued... A confidential interview revealed that the door to the laundry room must be left open for staff to observe clients. A review of a Special Incident Report submitted to CCL on 09/28/2024 revealed that while C1 was in the laundry area, "C1 made the choice to AWOL through the side door of the facility". A walk through performed by LPA Saeteurn on September 27, 2024, revealed that the facility has a washer and dryer on premises which is located in a room between the facility kitchen and garage/office area. The laundry room has three doorways, one leading to the garage/office area, one leading to the inside of the home kitchen area and a door leading to the outside of the home. LPA Saeteurn was able to see that the door leading to the side of the home gives access to an additional gate that leads to the driveway. Confidential interviews revealed that although clients are assigned a specific date to wash, C1 requested to use the washer on this day and staff approved it due to C1 having minimal clothing. A confidential interview confirmed that C1 was granted permission to use the laundry room on site and C1 proceeded to leave the facility to abscond. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 planned to abscond from the facility and communicated this to other residents. Confidential interviews revealed that clients were aware of C1's intentions to leave the facility, but it was not communicated to staff. Confidential interviews revealed that after S1 and S5 searched facility grounds for C1, an unauthorized protocol was enacted in which all parties were notified of C1 absconding. In reference to the allegation that staff did not ensure that minor attended school, confidential interviews and review of relevant client records confirmed that C1 was waiting for permanent placement to begin with Job Corps after being accepted into their program. The review of client records showed that C1 was attending school, however, conflicting confidential interview revealed that C1 was not enrolled in school. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 only attended the achievement center while placed at the facility which allowed for C1 to participate in education activities, sports, and field trips. A conflicting confidential interview revealed that the facility was allowed to complete the school enrollment process for C1 however, a conflicting confidential interview revealed that only the Authorized Representative and Educational Rights holder can make those decisions for minors in care. Confidential interviews revealed that C1's Education Rights Holder and Authorized Representative were contacted by the facility in an effort to help facilitate the process, however, neither C1's authorized representative nor educational rights holder ever completed the process. Continued... Continued... A review of the facility Program Statement revealed that if a client is not enrolled in school upon intake, the facility will work with the family to accomplish this goal and will include it on the service plan. Additionally, the program statement also included that the client would have free time at the facility to complete homework or can receive tutoring whether at a tutoring center or at the achievement center. Based on interviews conducted, LPA observation and record review, the allegations that staff did not prevent a physical altercation between children, staff did not supervise minor resulting in the minor AWOL'g from the facility and staff did not ensure that minor attended school are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Xavier Martinez,Program Director. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Xavier Martinez, Program Director whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

On March 4, 2025 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abby Saeteurn conducted an unannounced case management visit at the facility and met with Xavier Martinez, Program Director. The purpose of the case management visit is to obtain a signature and deliver an amended version of the LIC 9099 originally delivered on February 13, 2025. An exit interview was conducted with Xavier Martinez, Program Director. Copies of this report, the amended report, and appeal rights were provided to Xavier Martinez at the end of the visit.

It was reported that on March 10, 2024, C1 was threatening to kill and cut up Casa Nuestra staff and another minor in care. It was reported that on March 8, 2024, facility staff found a box cutter in the front yard of the facility and C1 put a metal wire in one of the facility's outlets causing a spark. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 were the only clients of the facility during the time frame reported. Confidential interviews and a review of pertinent facility records revealed that on March 10, 2024, C1 experienced a behavioral episode in which C1 was escalated and making threats of wanting to harm others. Confidential interviews revealed that the reason C1 was escalated was unknown, however, a review of facility records revealed C1 became escalated when refusing to turn over their cellphone for safeguarding. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 threatened to harm staff and C2, despite C2 not engaging with C1. Confidential interviews revealed that during C1's escalated behavior, C1 proceeded to stick a metal object into a facility outlet causing it to spark. A confidential interview revealed that days prior to the incident, facility staff found a knife outside of the facility which they believed belonged to C1. Confidential interviews revealed that the behavior C1 displayed was not something common and that there was no known history of C1 engaging in these kinds of behaviors. Confidential interviews revealed that in situations in which clients experience escalated behaviors, staff will attempt to help clients de-escalate prior to involving other mental health services. Confidential interviews revealed that staff attempted to help C1 de-escalate however, attempts were unsuccessful. A confidential interview revealed that due to the threats being made to C2 by C1, Staff each went separate ways with a client to create separation. Confidential interviews reveal that staff maintained contact with upper management and contacted the County of San Diego Mobile Crisis Response Team (MCRT) to assist. Confidential interviews revealed that staff followed MCRT's recommendation to contact the Psychiatry Emergency Response Team (PERT) due to the level of severity resulting in C1 being placed on a psychiatric hold. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that staff did not prevent minor from being threatened by another minor is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. Continued... An exit interview was conducted with Xavier Martinez, Program Director. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Xavier Martinez whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

met_with: Melissa Whitworth, House Supervisor/Group Home Administrator
narrative: On October 25, 2022, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lucero Jauregui, Eduardo Barragan conducted an announced annual facility inspection. LPA's met with Melissa Whitworth, House Supervisor/Group Home Administrator who provided LPA's with a guided tour of the facility both indoors and outdoors. The facility is a Three bedroom three bathroom (for client use) in this three story home. The basement floor consists of a bathroom, a bedroom, office space, a basement room (recreational room) and a laundry room. The common floor consisted off a Living room, kitchen, dinning area, and staff office. The third floor consisted of 2 bedrooms, 2 bathrooms and therapy room. All three bedrooms consisted of 2 bedrooms and all beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and all mattresses were in good repair. The backyard consisted off a patio set, a basketball court and two small sheds on the side of the home. One of the sheds was used for tools and was locked the second shed was used for emergency food and belongings. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The hot water temperature was measured in the main bathroom and is currently 110.0 degrees which is in ration. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility (8 cameras were noted on the premies of this facility.) Continued... Facility does not have a pool. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA's observed the following items posted Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policy, Facility sketch, Menu, and Emergency Plan. Medications were centrally stored and locked. During the inspection LPA's reviewed three staff personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. All licensing fees have been paid and are current at this time. LPA's also reviewed five client personal files and ensured that the client files contained all required documentation per Tittle Regulations. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date there was no deficiencies found at this time. However, one technical Violation is being administered per California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 regulation 80087(a)") A exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Melissa Whitworth, House Supervisor/Group Home Administrator.

On 04/02/2025 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Melissa Whitworth, House Supervisor/Administrator, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 11-17 years old. The current census is three youth. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a three story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with House Supervisor and included the following areas: three bedrooms, kitchen, four bathrooms (three client, one staff), dining room, living room, computer and recreation room, three staff offices, and an outdoor activity space. All required forms are posted including License, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in staff office on the main floor. LPA observed cameras at the facility in the front of the home, and there are cameras placed around the facility. No cameras were found in bedrooms. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. **Continued on LIC809-C**. **Continued from LIC809** Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The water temperature was tested in bathroom #3 which measured 117 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. There is one facility van that is on lease. There were no maintenance lights on. All client files are stored and maintained on both a locked cabinet, and on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed three client files and medication records to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed five out of 36 staff files to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored in a locked cabinet. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. LPA conducted two staff interviews, and all three clients refused to be interviewed. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted with House Supervisor. A copy of this report, and a Confidential Names List LIC811 were provided to House Supervisor. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file

Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility and deficiencies were cited under The Youth Homelessness Prevention Center (YHPC) Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) build on the current California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter General Licensing Requirements and Chapter Group Homes. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility Administrator.

met_with: Amba Johnson- Administrator, Ami Rowland-Chief Operating Officer and Paida Ndemera-Senior Vice President
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Dreamcatcher Youth Shelter. During the inspection, LPA met with Amba Johnson Administrator, Ami Rowland Chief Operating Officer (COO) and Paida Ndemera-Senior Vice President (SVP) and inspect the facility inside and out. The facility is licensed to served runaway and homeless youth. The facility consists of 5 bedrooms and Bathrooms (5 for client and Staff). The facility is a two level building with 3 kitchens, living room and conference rooms for meeting. The facility is licensed for 24 residents (all can be non-ambulatory) and currently 5 clients reside in facility. No more than four clients share a bedroom. At 02: PM LPA Rollins, Administrator, COO and SVP conducted a walk through of the facility inside and out. The kitchens is clean. License and signs are up to date and hanging up in clear sight. The hot water measured 114.6 degrees F in the sink,bathroom and bath tub. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication and knives are locked away. Medication logs are up to date. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. First aid kit is complete and fully stock. There are no bodies of water on the property. At 2: PM, LPA Rollins reviewed 5 client files with Administrator, COO and SVP. LPA observed all 5 client files to be complete, all documents were up to date and LPA found no deficiencies. At 3: PM, LPA observed 16 staff files with Administrator, COO and SVP. LPA observed staff files to be complete and documentation was update. LPA found no deficiencies. LPA observed all facility staff have completed there 20 hours annual training. LPA observed all training to be up to date and all certificates to be complete. During inspection, LPA receive an updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on October 19, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an unannounced annual / required inspection to the above facility on 7/30/2021 at 10: AM. During the inspection, LPA met with administrators Pactrick Buckalew and Ricardo Alveres who assisted with the inspection. LPA Belfield reviewed facility and staff files with Administrators. The facility is licensed to serve runaway and homeless youth. Currently there is one client ( C1) in the facility who arrived less than 10 hours before this inspection. Program has created an intake file for this client and LPA reviewed it during this inspection ( see LIC 811 dated 7/30/2021). At 11: AM LPA Belfield and both Administrators conducted walk through of the facility. The facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. Administrator Patrick states that the kitchen was recently remodeled. The water temperature was within the required regulation of under 120 degrees. LPA Belfield observed the facility to have more than a seven day supply of nonperishable and a more than a two day supply of perishable food. Medications are double locked and all proper information and forms are posted. Also observed were food menus, activity calendar, emergency exit signs by doors and fire extinguisher's, which were all serviced and up to date. All passageways are unobstructed, rooms are clean with proper linens on each bed, lots of storage is available for each client who enters. One client was sleeping and their room was not observed and they were not interviewed. There are no firearms on the property. During a review of employee files, LPA observed that the three staff did not have CPR / First Aid training up to date. During a discussion with administrator Patrick and Ricardo, it was stated that due to COVID-19, a lot of the training became restricted and hard to conduct as they normally would. Administrators have already started conducting and signing up staff for their training's and the three staff files that were reviewed were the last ones who had not yet completed their CPR / First Aid training. LPA Belfield was sent copies off all staff CPR training's minus the three. Advisory issued for Interim Licensing Standards, section 84575(c) Health-Related Services. Advisory Issued. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six or Interim Licensing standards that were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Patrick and a copy of this report and advisory note was sent to Administrator Patrick.

met_with: Ricardo Alvarez, Administrator & Jamere Crawford, Program Manager
narrative: On March 01, 2022 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to deliver findings of an investigation that was conducted by the Investigation Branch (IB) and completed on 01/24/22 by Investigator, Megan Mullen. During inspection, LPA Mendoza met with staff Ricardo Alvarez and Jamere Crawford. On 10/15/ Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an unusual incident report regarding neglect/ lack of supervision resulting in minor (C1) being sexually assaulted by another minor (C2) on several occasions while in care. (Please refer to LIC 811 for confidential names, dated 03/01/22). Based on the severity of the incident, the incident report was referred to IB and accepted as a full investigation. IB report, Case No: CD2621-10152. During the course of the investigation, IB reviewed bed check documentation, (C1) and (C2) Initial Service Assessment/Documents, Client shift notes, interviewed staff members, and clients. Based on confidential interviews and the information obtained it was reported that both clients flirted regularly and would hug on occasion. The facility issued a "flirt alert" between both clients. A flirt alert was intended to inform staff that they should keep a closer eye on (C2) and (C1) when they are together. Also, staff should not allow them alone. Staff were aware of the inappropriate interaction between both clients, and were notified to provide additional supervision. However, staff did not increase their supervision to monitor both clients closely, which resulted in five separate incidents of sexual contact between (C1) and (C2) that was non-consensual. [Please refer to LIC 809-C] In addition, another client (C3) on 10/13/21 requested staff to check in with (C1) because of (C2) sexually assaulting (C1). Which resulted in (C3) leaving the facility because (C3) did not feel safe. Based on the information obtained, there is preponderance of the evidence. Therefore, the above incident is Substantiated. The facility will be cited under The Youth Homelessness Prevention Center (YHPC) Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) build on the current California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter General Licensing Requirements and Chapter Group Homes. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility Administrator.

met_with: Administrator Ricardo Alvarez and Director of Health & Safety Katie Reisinger
narrative: On 3/27/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Assistant Program Administrator (APA) Angela Carmack conducted a random annual inspection. LPA and APA met with Administrator Ricardo Alvarez and Director of Health & Safety Katie Reisinger. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. The inspection consisted of a tour of facility and grounds, a review of facility files, personnel files, and client files, and interviews with 1 resident and 2 staff. The facility was observed to be clean, medications and sharps were locked away and inaccessible to clients, kitchen and bathrooms were sanitary, and bedrooms had clean linens and ample storage space. Common spaces were available to clients and were clean and organized. Personal rights and grievance procedures were available and accessible to clients. The following deficiencies were cited. (1) Hot water in the second floor client bathroom measured above the permitted range at 124. F. The water heater was lowered at visit. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80088. (2) Two staff members do not have a clearance associated to the facility. One staff has clearance documentation in the file, but one staff member has no clearance documentation. LPA notified of requirement that staff S1 and S2 (see LIC Confidential Names List, dated 3/27/23) not be on site until they have a background clearance associated to the facility. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 80019 and is assessing a civil penalty of $100 per day of violation up to 5 days, for a total of $500. (3) Personnel/Staff files are missing training documentation for staff S1, S2, S3, and S4 (see LIC 811), so LPA unable to verify annual training hours. LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84065. See attached LIC 809-Ds and LIC 421BG. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and copy of this report left with Administrator and Director of Health & Safety, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Ricardo Alvarez and Director of Health & Safety Katie Reisinger
narrative: On 4/12/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Ricardo Alvarez and Director of Health & Safety Katie Reisinger and informed of the purpose of the visit. On 10/26/22, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report (IR) that indicated that two residents, aged 13 and 17, had been caught together in a bedroom during the night bedroom checks on the night of 10/24/22. The younger resident alleged that the elder resident made sexual comments toward them and assaulted them. An investigation was conducted by CCL's Investigations Branch (IB), which found that it could not be determined that there was a lack of supervision leading to this incident occurring. Confidential interviews indicate that the residents were in the same bed together and were caught by staff and immediately separated. Review of the bed check logs indicated that at 10:20PM, the elder resident was asleep in bed, and from 10:40PM to 11:40PM, the younger resident was downstairs to get a glass of water and was talking to staff. Between 11:45PM and 12AM, a staff member was conducting bedroom checks and found the residents in the older resident's bedroom in the older resident's bed holding each other, with the younger resident making a statement that they were trying to help the older resident fall asleep. Later, though, the resident's narrative was inconsistent. The investigation also found that there was an occasion prior where female residents were found to have entered a male resident's room during the night and were directed by staff during night checks to go back to their rooms. The investigation found that the facility made reports to appropriate agencies, including CCL and law enforcement. Based on discussion with Administrator and Director of Health & Safety during this visit, the facility continues to conduct 20 minute room checks at minimum and will increase the frequency of checks when staff observe behaviors that cause concern. There are no deficiency citations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Ricardo Alvarez and Director of Health & Safety Katie Reisinger, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 2/21/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit in order to follow-up on a submitted incident report. On 4/8/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator Xanat Rodriguez and informed of the purpose of the visit. On 8/18/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility for a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator Xanat Rodriguez and informed of the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit was to follow-up on submitted incident reports regarding medication administration. LPA reviewed client medication records for the involved client and a current client in care who is prescribed medications. LPA also reviewed staff training records and training materials as well as documentation of the facility's follow-up actions to the incidents. The record review reflected that records were complete, that staff received instruction on medication procedures during onboarding, and that the facility reviewed procedures with the involved staff following the medication administration incidents. Administrator supplied LPA with requested copies of pertinent reviewed records. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Xanat Rodriguez.

On 9/2/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility for a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator Xanat Rodriguez and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on a review of client medication records, staff training records, and documentation of the facility's follow-up actions, on three days in July 2025, a psychotropic medication was not administered to a client as prescribed. A previous incident of medication not being administered as prescribed occurred in April 2025. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065. Personnel Duties, Subsection (b)(1). Refer to the attached LIC 809-D. A plan of correction was developed in consultation with Administrator. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator.

On November 4, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Hutton House with Salvador, Supervisor. LPA Barragan conducted a facility walk through and reviewed the client medications/records. While reviewing/counting the medications the Supervisor noticed that a pill was missing. The Supervisor asked his staff if they knew were the pill was and the staff member stated that they removed the client's pill and packaged it for the evening. LPA Barragan reviewed the regulations with the staff member and the Supervisor stating that "medications shall be stored in its original container and may not be transferred between containers". LPA Barragan noted that the one pill that was missing was locked and packaged in the safe. LPA Barragan notified the agency that is not permitted and if this were to happen in the future it would result in a citation. The Supervisor stated that he is going to conduct a retraining with staff to ensure this doesn't happen again. One technical violation is being issued on today's visit. LPA conducted exit interview with Salvador, Supervisor. LPA provided the summary report and appeal rights to Salvador as well upon completion.

On March 23, 2022 at 12:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Smith arrived at the facility to conducted an unannounced annual inspection visit. LPA Smith met with Donna Giddings, Administrator. The facility was toured inside and out. The facility is a group home that shelters children for up to 18 months. The facility has a capacity of 6 ambulatory female clients, ages 12-17 years old. Current census is 4 clients. The facility is a single story home with six bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. The facility is set up as follows: There are three bedrooms which each have two twin beds in them. The bedrooms have adequate dresser and closet space. There are two bedrooms used by staff. One with a king bed and one with a queen bed . One bedroom is used for Administrator and spouse and the other bedroom is used for respite parent. There is one bedroom which is not currently being occupied. Three of the bathrooms are used by all the clients. The cleaning products are stored and locked in the garage. The knives, sharps, and medications are stored in the locked staff office in a locked cabinet. Medications logs were reviewed. Four of four client files were reviewed. Three of three staff files were reviewed. All adults residing in the home have fingerprint clearances. The Administrator and Therapist office is locked and store the staff and client files. The client and staff records are located and locked in the staff office in file cabinets. LPA observed that there are no bodies of water on premises. Per licensee there are no firearms or weapons on premises. LPA observed four therapeutic animals on facility grounds. There are two goats, and two pigs. --------- The facility kitchen is currently being remodeled and is scheduled to be completed Thursday, March 25, 2022. LPA observed sufficient food supply, including a sufficient supply of fresh fruits, vegetables, can goods, and staples. No expired food was located in the supply. The facility has a sufficient supply of sheets, bedding and linens located in the hall closet. The hot water temperature was 127 degrees Fahrenheit. Administrator was advised to lower the temperature on the water heater. There are operable smoke/carbon monoxide detectors located in the bedrooms and hallways and are in good working order. There are four fire extinguishers with current certification throughout the facility. The facility staff uses a facility van that seats eight to transport the clients. Based on Evaluation there were no deficiencies cited during today's inspection. The facility is within Title 22 regulation standards at this time. Exit interview conducted, copy of LIC 809 report was provided.

**This is an Amendment to the Amendment of the original document on 03/10/2025** On March 10, 2025, at 02: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Mutialu arrived at the facility for the purposes of performing a case management annual continuation inspection, which was started on 03/03/2025. LPA met with Facility Manager, Jenna Arroyo. LPA advised (JA), that during the inspection on 3/03/2025 they were cited for the incorrect regulation in the original report, which was amended, and the citation will be reflected in this case management. In addition, on 03/07/ Administrator, Derrick Burton provided the Personnel Report (LIC 500) which was cross referenced with Guardian to ensure all employees had background clearances. LPA's review indicated that Staff (S2, S5, S7, and S8) did not have a criminal background clearance per Guardian. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division 6, regulation 80019(e)(2): Criminal Records Clearance. Record review confirm S2 and S5 worked in facility for 137 days from 10/18/24 to 03/03/25, and S7 and S8 worked in the facility for 374 days from 03/01/24 to 03/10/25 without criminal record clearance. An immediate civil penalty is issued for $2000($ X 4 staff per day, to a maximum of five days). As a result of today's inspection, one deficiency is being cited and civil penalties are being assessed in the amount of $2000 in accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 80019(e)(2). (see LIC809D). An exit interview was conducted with the Facility Manager, Jenna Arroyo. The report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Facility Manager at the time of the inspection.

narrative: On July 8, 2021 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Anastasia Flores and Bobatunde Aborchie arrived and met with (RHYS) Run Away Homeless Youth Shelter, Facility Manager, Shelly Thomas. LPA's disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Youth Advocate, Larieya Boyd. There was one staff and five clients present at the time of inspection. At 10: AM, the facility was toured inside and out with Ms. Boyd and Ms. Thomas. The home is a two-story residence with three bedrooms and four bathrooms. Downstairs: Dining room equipped with large table and 8 chairs There is a client bathroom downstairs next to family room, with a toilet and sink in operable working order. At 10: AM, hot water temperature was measured at 115.5 degrees and met the regulation requirement between 105 and 120 degrees. Family room was equipped with couches, coffee table, and a fireplace that was properly screened. Living room was equipped with adequate lighting, large sofa, coffee table, television and games. Open kitchen area is used for meal prepping. LPA observed pots, pans, lids, dishware, eating utensils, cooking utensils, cups, mugs and all the large kitchen appliances. All sharp knives are locked in a box and stored in staff office. There was an emergency supply of perishable foods located in the pantry. The trash can in the kitchen was observed to have no lid and LPAs advised the staff to have a lid placed on for health reasons. Staff informed LPAs that a client had broken the lid and it will be replaced immediately. First aid kit and locked box to keep medications and knives was observed in closet of staff office. There is a small refrigerator in the office to store refrigerated medications. There was also a bathroom located in the office, with operable shower, sink and toilet. Locked supply closet with cleaning supplies, brooms near the front door. Laundry room with washer and dryer are located downstairs. The door from laundry room to the garage is kept locked at all times and is used for storage. LPAs observed piles of donated clothes in the garage and it was noted to have the clothes put away or removed to trash as to not create such a clutter. Posted items included Personal Rights, Clients Grievance Procedures and Foster Care Ombudsman Poster. () Upstairs: Bedroom #1 designated for 2 clients. 2 twin size beds equipped with mattress pads and comforter. There is a closet available for client use. There was no screen on the window and the screen was sitting behind the bedroom door with a hole. Bedroom #2 designated for 2 clients. 2 twin size beds equipped with mattress pads and comforter, full dresser and closet available for client use. There was no screen on the window. Bedroom #3 designated for 2 clients. 2 twin size beds equipped with mattress pads and comforter, 2 full dressers and closet. The window was open with no screen on the window. There is a hallway restroom designated for male client use, with operable sink, toilet and shower. At 10: AM the hot water temperature was measured at 114.6 degrees and met the regulation requirement. There was an open Windex bottle under the sink, it was immediately removed and placed in the locked cabinet. LPA observed extra supplies of towels, comforters and linens. Intake/Therapy office equipped with desk, chairs, white boards, office supplies, operational supplies. Inside the staff office there is another bathroom utilized by female clients, the main lights are currently not working and need to be replaced. Smoke detectors in each bedroom were observed and carbon monoxide detector located upstairs, downstairs and in common areas are in working order. Posted items included Personal Rights, Clients Grievance Procedures and Foster Care Ombudsman Poster. Outdoor: Front yard is safe and free of hazards, there was trash observed on the side of house and was immediately removed by Ms. Thomas. Backyard is safe and free of hazards. There were table and chairs in a covered patio available for client use. LPAs observed a broken basketball court, informed by Ms. Thomas that it was broken due to the wind. It was discussed with facility representatives to have it removed for safety of clients. There was no pool or other bodies of water. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. LPAs observed four window screens missing, one in bedroom 1, bedroom 2, bedroom 3 and one in the upstairs female client's bathroom. There were window screens observed that need to be properly adjusted to the windows, one on the front outside window and one on the back-upstairs window intake/therapy office. There were two-bedroom doors with holes #1, #3 and one wall upstairs damaged that needed to be repaired. The pile of clothes in the garage are going to be cleaned up today per Ms. Thomas. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Shelly Thomas. () Five of five client files were reviewed during the inspection. Staff files are kept at the human resources office down the street and will be reviewed at a later time. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. There was no updated staff roster posted. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there was two deficiencies cited at this time; Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1; Article 07. Section; 80088 (b) Furniture, fixtures, equipment and supplies; there were four window screens missing. A technical violation LIC TV was issued for the clean up of the clothes in the garage, damaged doors and holes in walls. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, 809D and LIC 9102 and appeal rights was provided to the Shelly Thomas.

On June 21, 2023, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, arrived at the Group Home (GH) and met with Youth Homelessness Prevention Center(YHPC), Shelter Manager, Nike Hanson. LPA notified the shelter manger of the reason for the subsequent annual/random continuation visit. LPA was greeted and granted access by the shelter manager. The annual was initiated on June 20, 2023, at which time physical plant, operations, and emergency intervention sections of the care tool were completed. There were three staff present and three clients present at the time of the inspection. During today's visit, LPA inspected disaster preparedness and staffing record sections. LPA also interviewed three out of three clients. LPA reviewed the LIC 500 and determined all staff are associated with the facility. Staff files were reviewed for staff 1, staff 2, staff 3, staff 4, and staff 5, and the LPA observed the following: Staff 2, staff 3, and staff 4 do not have a facility manager job description in their staff file. Staff 2 does not have a lead advocate job description and staff 5 has no job description in their staff files. Staff 5 does not have a health screening or tuberculosis test in the staff file. There is no evidence facility manager training has been provided for staff 1, staff 2, staff 3, staff 4, and staff 5. Staff 1, staff 2, staff 3, staff 4, and staff 5 are missing oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications training in their staff file. There is no written plan for the development, maintenance, and implementation training for facility manager for staff 1, staff 2, staff 3, staff 4, and staff 5. The facility had posted a disaster plan dated 07/13/2021. However, the licensee, administrator, or regulated individual did not sign and date the documentation to indicate that the plan had been reviewed and updated as necessary. The shelter manager updated the plan during today's visit. (Continued next page) Based on record review and confirmation by the administrator and shelter manager of missing documentation, the licensee did not comply and is cited for the following sections: Personnel Records 84066(b)(1); Personnel Requirements 80065(g)(1), 84065(d)(3), 84065(j)(4)(A), 84065(k). Additionally, the facility will receive a technical violation (TV) for Other Provisions 1565(d). LPA will need to return at a later date to continue the annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted with the shelter manager and the Administrator, Devin Baze, was on the phone. A copy of this report, LIC 811, 809D's, TV, and appeal rights was explained and provided to the Nike Hanson.

narrative: On August 15, 2023, at 2:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Val Wilson, LPA Nicole Strickland, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith and Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook met with Family Assistance Program (FAP) Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and My Place Administrator Darryl Evey, Chief Operating Officer (COO) Ken Weekes, My Place Shelter Manager Fatima Herrera, Our House Shelter Manager Joe Mendoza, Our House Social Worker Julie Ann Ferreira, Board Member John Perring-Mulligan, Board Member Kierre Coghill, CDSS System of Care (SOC) Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager Alicia Bernstein, SOC Policy Analyst Chris Meyer, SOC Health Program Specialist I Hong Luu, SOC Policy Analyst Gina Jones, Child Trafficking Research and Policy Unit Analyst Leland Turner, Catalyst Center Senior Program Advisor Misty Berard and Kelsie Tatum Martinez, San Bernardino County Children and Family Services (SBCCFS) Shelter Coordinator Amy Mierzwi, SBCCFS Deputy Director Nancy Satterwhite, SBCCFS Assistant Director Jonathan Byers, SBCCFS PRD Tracy Raymond and SBCCFS PRD Ana del Nogal; Department of Behavioral Health (DBH) San Bernardino County Dianne Wolkenhauer, PhD, Department of Health Care Services Staff Services Manager Dave Gutierrez and Central Placement Unit Supervisor Christina Lopez via Microsoft Teams for a virtual informal office conference. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the following issues and concerns with the Licensee for both Our House and My Place facilities: Administrator qualifications and duties, lack of administrative oversight, staff training, plan of correction, lack of trauma informed care, personal rights, and lack of supervision concerning the Our House facility. The three areas of concern applicable to the My Place facility are lack of administrative oversight, Administrator qualifications and duties and Plan of correction. Administrator qualifications and duties - LPM Smith advised there are concerns regarding the Administrator's lack of knowledge regarding specific incidents that have occur in the facility, lack of knowledge of the clients in care and the needs and services of the clients in care, and Administrator referring (Continued on page 2) Pg 2 (Continued from page 1) Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives to the Facility Manager, Joe Mendoza for information. The concerns cover the period of February 2022, when the Administrator of Our House was Darryl Evey until present. CEO stated that they are in the process of having facility administrators present at the facilities for 40 hours per week. They are also in the process of hiring a Director that will be overseeing the Administrators. Lack of oversight- LPM Smith advised there are concerns that the Administrator is not familiar with the regulations and there is a breakdown in communication amongst the staff. RM Cook stated there should be oversight by the Administrator and Board of Directors for all facility operations. CEO stated reports are emailed to CEO and he works on the outcome. Each month there is a board meeting and they go over special incident reports and Licensing reports. They also have a leadership meeting each week to go over pending issues. SBCCFS PRD Tracy Raymond shared improvements observed with Our House since the implementation of new youth and shelter protocols that San Bernardino county provides assist with, including CFTMs being initiated immediately, internal meetings every other week with FAP. The addition of Social Worker Julie Ann who comes from a trauma informed focus has been a strong positive influence over the last year. There are also supportive actions like peer advocates meeting with the youth to assist youth to adjust to being in a shelter. Tracy reported that Our House accepts placement for a broad spectrum of youth that are difficult to place and STRTP's are no longer willing to work with. If FAP calls the county emergency hotline, San Bernardino county representatives report to the facility and remove youth as necessary from placement to assist with de-escalation of emergency situations and crisis intervention. Tracy stated San Bernardino county is improving their practice and are helping FAP improve in their operations, working together as a partnership. Staff training- RM Cook advised there are concerns regarding a lack of staff training being reported from information gathered during complaint investigations and the annual inspections. CEO stated they began documenting the ongoing training a year ago when CCL brought this to their attention. Staff training is done every other Thursday, debriefing is done during staff meetings, along with scheduling staff, and outside agency training is provided. The process to onboard is four months and staff turnover averages at four months, leaving continued staffing issues as a primary struggle. As an incentive, the benefit of a half-paid day off has been implemented and additionally there are more outdoor activities which help the staff's mental health. (Continued to page 3) Pg 3 (Continued from page 2) Representative from the Catalyst Center, Misty Berard shared they are available for support and shared the following links: mberard@catalyst-center.org; kmartinez@catalyst-center.org; https://catalyst-center.teachable.com/courses; https://catalystcenter.learnupon.com/store Plan of correction (POC)- LPM Smith advised that Joe from Our House and Fatima of My Place submit plan of corrections in a timely manner. There are concerns with the plan of correction from Nike of My Place and Devin of Our House not being submitted on time and verbally stating the plan of correction will be late. LPA Valerie Wilson has reminded them that the request for an extension for the plan of correction needs to be submitted and approved by CCL prior to the due date. LPM Smith advised if plan of correction is not received by the due date and there has not been an extension approved by CCL for the plan of correction due date the facility can be assessed civil penalties. CEO stated that Fatima's Administrator qualifications were turned in to CCL for My Place. Fatima will ensure that the plan of corrections are done properly. The current Administrator for Our House, Devin, will be separating employment from Our House at the end of the month and a new Administrator will be hired at Our House. The Board has done some interviews to fill the Administrator position. CEO complained that previous administrator packets took longs periods of time to approve and possibly Joe Mendoza can be designated during CCL's review of the administrator packet. RM Cook stated that the turnaround time for administrator qualifications review should be less than two weeks if the statement of qualification, and the correct documents are all provided in a timely manner to the LPA, and the candidate meets regulation requirements. If additional information is needed from the facility the turnaround time may be longer. Lack of trauma informed care- RM Cook advised that there have been substantiated complaints and case managements involving violations of personal rights that imply a lack of trauma informed care being provided by the facility staff. CEO stated their staff receive a lot of harm reduction and trauma informed care trainings. SOC Alicia Bernstein provided an overview of trauma informed care and provide resources. Child Trafficking Research and Policy Unit Analyst Leland Turner discussed harm reduction and provided resources and links for support. leeland.turner@dss.ca.gov (Continued to page 4) Pg 4 (Continued from page 3) https://www.cdss.ca.gov/Portals/9/ACIN/2019/I-28_19.pdf?ver=2019-07-23-145815-020, ACIN I-28-19 (July 22, 2019) Harm Reduction Series - Social Worker, ACIN I-50-19 (July 29, 2019) Harm Reduction Series - Probation Officer, ACIN I-36-21 (June 22, 2021) Harm Reduction Series - Law Enforcement, ACIN I- 31-22 (April 8, 2022), Harm Reduction Series - Caregiver and ACIN I-59-18 (September 14, 2018) Introduction to the Harm Reduction Strategies Series Regarding Commercially Sexually Exploited Children. Personal rights and Lack of supervision- LPM Smith discussed several substantiated complaints regarding personal rights and lack of supervision from 2022 to present. LPM Smith summarized deficiencies cited. LPM Smith informed the Licensee of the Technical Support Program (TSP), stating it is a branch that can work with FAP in various areas they may need support in regarding facility operations. A referral can be made but it is voluntary. CEO stated their intention was never to work with foster youth, but there was a need and CFS asked the facility for support. CEO stated foster youth are much more difficult than the runaways and respond differently to the support, and support with crisis intervention would be appreciated. LPM Smith advised FAP to identify any areas they may need support to CCL and CCL will submit a TSP referral. Tracy Raymond stated the harm reduction training and resources provided by the Child Trafficking Research and Policy Unit is super informative for harm reduction and collaboration. Tracy also stated that San Bernardino county understands the responsibility they have in this situation and will continue to partner with the facility to help with compliance issues. CEO stated that he was not in agreement with CCL findings. RM Cook advised that FAP has the right to appeal and there are times the appeal is heard and findings are overturned. SBCCFS Deputy Director Nancy Satterwhite stated the county has looked at ways to collaborate and how to "team" placement combinations for youth in care. Peer family advocates are connected with the youth and it has been beneficial. San Bernardino county will also be hosting a mandated reporter training at Our House and looking at the contracts with the County for extra supports services that can be implemented. The CEO reported feeling better about the interaction with DCFS and how they are removing the clients to help the Program succeed along with the new contract that includes a new crisis intervention protocol. RM Cook reminded that regulatory enforcement and compliance is provided to protect the health and safety of youth in care and CCL hopes that the Licensee will take advantage of the assistance, collaboration, and all resources offered and provided by CCL and each department represented in the meeting. (Continued to page 5) Pg 5 (Continued from page 4) The licensee is being requested to submit a Plan of Action for each of the focus areas above including the following: - How will the Board of Directors ensure appropriate administrative oversight is implemented? - Submit an updated LIC 500 for the hours that will be worked by the Administrator and facility staff -How will the Board review complaints, what information will be included in board meeting minutes, and how will the Board address issue client health and safety issues as they arise? - How will the facility ensure staff training is completed. - How will the facility ensure staff have knowledge of the program statement? - How will the facility ensure staff know how to implement appropriate crisis intervention? - How will the facility ensure the plan of corrections are completed and submitted to CCL by the due date? - How will the facility ensure trauma informed care is being provided? - How will the facility ensure the personal rights of clients are not being violated by staff? - How will the facility ensure that staff are adequately supervising the clients? The Plan of Action response will be submitted to CCL by August 29, 2023. If more time is needed to submit the plan of action or there are any questions, please contact LPA Valerie Wilson at valerie.wilson@dss.ca.gov or (951) 897-9155. A copy of this report was emailed to CEO Darryl Evey for electronic signature. The signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On October 16, 2023 at 1:50 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with My Place Group Home Youth Homelessness Prevention Center, Administrator Fatima Herrera via telephone and Shelter manager Judith MendozA in person, to deliver a case management deficiencies report. Information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) revealed there have been several requests for youth and facility records requested by CCL's Special Investigator (SI) Wilfredo Vasquez. The dates of these requests include September 22, 2023, October 4, 2023, and October 11, 2023. These requests were made to house manager Estephanie Fajardo, Shelter Manager Mendoza, and Director Steinhart by SI Vasquez. The facilities lack of response to the provide the requested documents is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 84544(d). Based on confidential interview and record review there is a preponderance of evidence the facility has not ensured requested documents were made available to SI. The facility is being cited for violation of Youth Homeless Prevention Center Interim Licensing Standard (ILS) 84544(d) INSPECTION AUTHORITY OF LICENSING AGENCY (d) The licensing agency shall have the authority to inspect, audit, and copy youth or youth homelessness prevention center records upon demand during normal business hours. Records may be removed if necessary for copying. Removal of records shall be subject to the requirements specified in Section 84570(e) and California Code of Regulations, Title 22 and Section 80066(c), which posed a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to My Place Group Home Youth Homelessness Prevention Center, Shelter Manager Judith Mendoza.

narrative: Facility Evaluation Report (LIC 809) created in error.

Licensing Program Analyst arrived to My Place CA-18W, Apple Valley CA 92307 and met with Shelter Manager, Nike Hanson to deliver an amended document initially delivered to the facility on March 12, 2024.

Record review also revealed S1 had been concerned with C1 being placed at the facility due to age and other behaviors. Confidential interviews provided consistent statements of S1 being the only staff on shift at the time C1, C2, and C3 were alone upstairs and S1 was downstairs. Confidential interviews and record review revealed S1 neglected S1's personal duty to provide the supervision, protection and care of C1, when C1, C2, and C3 were found by S2 in an upstairs room of the facility with the door closed. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging lack of supervision resulted in minor's (Child #1 [C1]'s) personal rights being violated is substantiated. The complaint allegation is valid because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) regulation 84065.2(b)(1) PERSONAL DUTIES: (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children individually and in groups at all times. The facilities violation of CCR 84065.2(b)(1) PERSONAL DUTIES requires the facility to be assessed an immediate civil penalty per Health and Safety Code 1548(c)(3). An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with Civil Penalty assessment and appeal rights to My Place Shelter Manager, Nike Hanson,.

narrative: On December 11, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted a Case Management Pre-licensing inspection, component II and Component III tele Inspection via Microsoft teams at Noah's Anchorage Youth Shelter and LPA met With Facility Administrator (FA), and Facility Manager (FM) via Microsoft Teams. This is a five bedroom, two and half bath, two story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area, a therapy room and a staff office. No clients are residing in the home during the time of the inspection. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. Staff #1 states there are no guns or weapons in the home. On 10/12/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with Karen Arellano, Lead Residential Caseworker who granted tour and access to the facility. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to run away and homeless youth for up to ninety (90) days for children ages twelve (12) to seventeen (17) years old, ambulatory only. During the visit there were no clients present in the facility. The facility is located in a residential area. The facility is a two (2) story home. The first floor has the staff office and two (2) client bedrooms, one (1) client bathroom, staff bathroom, kitchen/dining area, living room and garage. First floor has access to the garage which has been converted into client's study area, laundry room and storage. The garage area has storage for soap, laundry and cleaning supplies. There is also a refrigerator in the garage that is being utilized to store extra perishable food items. The kitchen is equipped with a stove, sink, and kitchen utensils. All sharp items are locked and inaccessible to clients. Menus are posted in the kitchen. There are snacks and fruits readily available for the clients to eat in kitchen counter. There is sufficient perishable and non-perishable food items in the facility. There is a fire extinguisher located next to the kitchen/dining area. The living room has a couch and television. Clients' rights are posted in the first floor hallway. There is a private room being utilized for private meetings, phone calls and intake located on the first floor. The staff office has locked cabinets used to store disinfectants, toiletries, and client medications. Staff files are stored in the staff office room. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong conducted four (4) staff record reviews and two (2) staff interviews. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility. Client record review and interviews will be completed on a later date.

On 10/13/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Vanessa Loza, Program Director who granted tour and access to the facility. During the visit, no clients were present in the facility. There is a total of four (4) fire extinguishers throughout the facility. There are four (4) working fire/carbon monoxide alarms in the facility. A disaster/evacuation plan is posted in the facility. Staff conducts emergency drills once a month. There is an Automated External Defibrillator machine located in the staff office to be used in case of an emergency. All staff have updated First Aid/CPR certification. First aid kit is supplied with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic, bandages and other medical supplies and is available to use in case of an emergency. All staff are trained with care and supervision, child abuse reporting, medical care administration, trauma informed care and other required trainings for congregate care staff. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights and child abuse. Children are accorded with their personal rights and needs. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Staff coordinate and connect clients with appropriate resources and referrals to local government agencies and organizations to help youth secure a suitable placement. There are a total of four (4) client bedrooms in the facility; two (2) bedrooms are located on the first floor and two (2) bedrooms are located on the second floor. Each bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds, pillows, sturdy mattresses and clean linens. Each bedroom has sufficient storage and adequate lighting. There is a desk and chair for youth to use inside the bedroom. There are (2) full sized bathrooms clients can use in the facility. Both bathrooms are equipped with a working toilet, shower and sink. Faucets used by clients for personal use have hot water. All bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good working condition. (Page 1 of 2) There is sufficient supplies of toiletries and hygiene products for the clients. The outdoor space has recently been remodeled. The outdoor space is fenced in and was observed to be free of flies and other insects. All outdoor and indoor passageways were observed to be free of debris and obstruction. All window screens were observed to be clean and in good condition during the visit. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA Karnsrithong concluded the required annual inspection for the facility. Exit interview was conducted with the Program Director and a copy of this report was provided to the facility. (Page 2 of 2)

On 1/28/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA)Nancy O'Connell conducted an Annual/Required inspection, at Noah's Anchorage Youth Shelter. LPA met with Vanessa Loza, Facility Administrator (FA). This is a four bedroom, two and half bath, two story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area, a therapy room, two staff offices and a private room used for confidential phones calls/therapy sessions. No clients are residing in the home during the time of the inspection. There is no swimming pool or body of water on the premises. There are no guns or weapons in the home. Required postings are visible in the main hallway. There are 4 fire extinguishers observed and fully charged. Carbon monoxide/fire alarms were tested and found to be operational during inspection. LPA confirmed criminal record clearances for all staff listed on the LIC500. LPA confirmed that a change of administrator was completed within the last year and that all required documents have been reviewed and approved with the Department. During the time of the inspection LPA observed the following: Bedroom #1(downstairs) has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space, a desk and closet. Bedroom #2(downstairs) has two twin size beds, adequate closet/drawer space and a closet. Bedroom #3(upstairs) has two twin size beds, adequate closet/drawer space and a closet Bedroom #4(upstairs) has two twin size beds, adequate closet/drawer space and a closet Continued on LIC809C Staff office (upstairs) is being utilized as a staff office and has two desks, two computers, file cabinets. It is used as the administrators office as well as a meeting room with clients/families. Living room (downstairs): enough seating for five individuals, tv, movies, games Kitchen: refrigerator, stove, microwave, available snacks on the counter, locked/secured trashdrawer, locked knife drawer was observed adjacent to the stove and contained an inventory sheet with knife count. Refrigerator was stocked with fresh food, and kept at required temp. Pantry closet ((located in hallway): this closet was stocked with non-perishable items. Bathroom (downstairs): contained a standing shower, sink, toilet, hand-wash items. Temperature was found to be within required limits. Half bathroom (downstairs): located in main hallway: used primarily for staff but can be used for clients when needed. There is a door that leads outside of the facility located next to this bathroom. Garage (attached): there is a garage that is utilized as a multipurpose/activity room. There are large couches, long tables for gathering, a laundry area, three computer stations, a closet filled with arts/crafts tools, and locked cabinets that hold detergent products. There is a door that leads to the back yard. Backyard: there are two gates that allow for entrance to the backyard, but one is kept locked for safety, while the other gate located near the main entrance of the facility is always kept unlocked. There are multiple tables available for leisure, a BBQ that is kept secure while not in use, and areas used for gardening. Front yard: the front of the facility is gated, and has a ramp leading to the front entrance. LPA conducted 2 file reviews for S1 and S, [see LIC Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 1/28/25, for names]. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children are encouraged to attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the Annual Review. Per California Code of Regulations, Title Regulations, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 5, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the FA.
