On December 18, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore arrived at Our Stay Youth Homelessness Prevention Center-Group Home for a scheduled pre-licensing inspection. LPA and LPM were met at the facility by Administrator Fatima Herrera, Director of Youth Shelters Sylvia Steinhart, and Shelter Manager Joseph Mendoza This facility is applying for a license to operate a Homeless Center with a capacity of six clients. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. The home is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1- It consisted of two single beds. The beds were missing linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #2- It consisted of two single beds. The beds were missing linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3- It consisted of two single beds. The beds were missing linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #4- It consisted of a single bed, a dresser, and a desk. This room is being converted to an office. The bed and dresser will be removed according to the applicants. The bedroom was missing supplies. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. Applicants were made aware that clients of opposite sex, over the age of 5, require separate bedrooms. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closet space for client's belongings, however all beds were missing sheets. All hazardous items will be stored in bedroom 4 to be converted into staff office. The medications and confidential files will be locked and stored in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals will be locked and stored in the staff office's closet. No Sharp objects were observed during the inspection. There was no First Aid kit at the facility. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Administrator Fatima Herrera. The hot water temperature was not in the proper temperature. Applicants understand that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Proper storage of all food was discussed, however there was no food in the refrigerator. The kitchen did not have a trash with lid for waste. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Visitation policies were not posted at this time. The garage was separated from the house with an external door and will be utilized for storage only. The backyard where clients will have access to play is completely fenced, however there was weed and dirt residue around the house. There is no pool or other bodies of water. LPM and LPA did not observe any safe, clean, and age-appropriate educational supplies and games for the age group of clients to be cared for both inside and outside the facility. Prior to licensure the following items are needed: 1. Hot water heater must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. 2. All client beds need to have linen, comforters, sheets, and pillows. 3. Fire alarm system is not synchronizing and were not working properly. 4. First Aid kits with all required items. 5. Food supplies for the clients to serve. 6. A Trash can with lid in kitchen area. 7. Adequate cleaning supplies 8. Bedroom 4 needs to be free of one bed, a dresser to be converted a locked staff office. 9. Games, educational supplies, and any adequate equipment for the clients to serve. 10. Hygiene supplies for the clients to serve. 11. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, Visitation policies need to be posted. 12. Backyard free of debris. 3. A Component III Orientation needs to be scheduled when the corrections are completed. Based on the inspection of the home on this date, the facility did not appear to be in compliance with the Community Care Licensing Division Title Laws and Regulations.

Applicants were made aware that clients of opposite sex, over the age of five, require separate bedrooms. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for client's belongings. All hazardous items will be stored in bedroom 4 to be converted into staff office. The medications and confidential files will be locked and stored in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals will be locked and stored in the staff office's closet. First Aid kit at the facility is located in the staff office. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Administrator Fatima Herrera. The hot water temperature was observed to be at appropriate temperature. Applicants understand that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. The kitchen trash was observed to have a lid. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Visitation policies were observed posted. The garage was separated from the house with an external door and will be utilized for storage only. The backyard where clients will have access to play is completely fenced and free of weeds and dirt residue around the house. There is no pool or other bodies of water. On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst Brian Bertoli made an unannounced visit to the facility. The purpose of the visit was to determine the operational status of the facility. Recent news reports indicated the SAY organization was having financial difficulties and had laid off most of their employees. LPA Bertoli knocked on both front doors and rang the doorbell and their was no response. The doors were locked and there was no sign of activity on the premises. There appeared to be a lack of maintenance by leaves covering the walkways. There was a sign on the ground indicating "Staff and drop in services are currently unavailable' with a number to call for a crisis line - 888 729-0012. LPA Bertoli called the number and left a voicemail message asking for status of the facility.

On July 3,2025 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility.. LPA met with Facility Administrator Melissa Whitworth and Program Director, Lisa Samaan. The facility is a three bedroom two bathroom two story home with an attached garage. The applicant is applying for a Group Home Youth Center Homelessness Prevention Center with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 12-17 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Clients will have access to use multiple cordless telephones to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a first aid kit that has all of the required items. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked in storage closet. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Medication will be locked and stored in a cabinet in the staff office The following required forms need to be posted in the facility: Personal Rights, LIC Emergency Disaster Plan, and Grievance Policy, and Removal and/or planned discharge policy. The facility is set up as follows The entry hallway leads in two directions, to the right an open living room that flows into the study hall and to the left a hallway leads to the dining room and attached kitchen. The open study hall area for clients has desks and chairs with a printer to complete school work and meet with a tutor. The dinning room is located next to the kitchen and contains dining room table where meals will had in family style. The kitchen is attached to dining area and contains dishwasher, fridge and other small appliances. At the rear of the home past the dining room is a staff office that will contain staff and client files, centrally stored medication and other facility logs. All shared living spaces have furniture in good condition. This area also contained books, television and other recreational items. There are three client bedrooms that are designated for two clients per room with twin sized beds dresser and closet space for each client. Bedroom #1 is located downstairs: it designated for two clients, with two twin beds, two dressers and closet spaces. Bathroom #1 is located downstairs: It is located inside of bedroom #1 for client use. Bedroom #2 is located upstairs: it is designated for two clients, two twin beds, it has two dressers and closet space. Bathroom #2 is located upstairs: It is shared by clients in bedrooms #2 and # Bedroom #3 is located upstairs: it is designated for two clients, two twin beds, two dressers and closet space. Bathroom #3 is located downstairs next to laundry area: it is designated for guest use. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses pads. Each bedroom had adequate lighting. LPAs observed the following areas that need to be corrected: Posting the required forms and information Seven days supplies of nonperishable food 2 days supplies of perishable food 3 day of emergency supply food Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility will make the corrections and provide LPA Munoz will verification of items purchased and posted to complete pre licensing inspection. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. LPAs conducted exit interview with Facility Administrator, Melissa Whitworth and Program Director, Lisa Samaan and provided them with a copy of this report.

met_with: Maria Isabel Kluwe and Gail Munoz Salinas
narrative: On July 13, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan travelled to CSP Huntington to conduct an annual inspection with Maria Isabel Kluwe, Program Director Of Client Care and Gail Munoz Salina, House Supervisor. An inspection of the facility was conducted, and the following was observed: There are currently six clients in placement. LPA toured the facility indoors and outdoors. The fire extinguisher was charged and up to date. Hot water temperatures last measured up to 104 degrees in the home. LPA observed adequate supply of non-perishables. LPA observed adequate supply of furnishings, linen and storage space for clients. Cleaning chemicals were inaccessible to clients. Medication area was centrally stored and locked. There are no pets at the facility. Per the Administrator and House Supervisor, there are no weapons at the facility. There were no pools at the facility. LPA Barragan will be returning to complete the annual inspection at a later date and time.

On March 13, 2025, at 09: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Administrator/Program Director, Nancy Galeana, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. LPA Marquez and Administrator Nancy Galeana toured the physical plant, outside and inside. Review of the facility's operations shows that the facility is licensed to serve twelve clients ages 11 - 17 years of age. The facility currently has three clients in care at this time, and there were three clients present during the inspection. LPA Marquez noted that the facility has an interior and exterior camera system that monitors the common areas of the facility. Facility has six bedrooms, with separation of three bedrooms on the east side of facility to occupy six female clients and three bedrooms on the south side of facility to occupy six male clients. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. There is a fireplace located in the living room which is properly screened. There is a staff office located next to the dining room and game room. The client and staff records are located and locked in the staff office in file cabinets. There is also a school room, social worker's office, and director's office. The medication and first-aid kit are stored in the locked medication cabinet in the staff office. There was only one client taking prescribed medication at the time of this inspection. The medication log was kept updated. The cleaning products and sharps are stored in the locked closet near dining area. The facility is clean, organized and in good repair. The facility has a sufficient supply of sheets, bedding and linens. **Continued on LIC809-C** **Continued from LIC809** Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The facility's smoke detectors in bedrooms and hallways were checked and were operable. All smoke detectors are connected to a fire safety monitoring agency contracted by the city due to the building being owned by the city of Huntington Beach. A copy of the alarm system maintenance check that was conducted on 02/10/2025 was given to LPA. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator Galeana. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. Hot water temperature was tested at 116.3 degrees Fahrenheit in the boys bathroom, which is within regulatory requirements of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. LPA observed a minimum seven day non-perishable, and a two day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. Three staff (S1 - S3) out of thirty-two staff were interviewed, and two of three clients (C1 and C2) were interviewed as part of the inspection. A sample of client and staff files were reviewed during the inspection. LPA reviewed two out of five volunteer files (S6-S7). LPA reviewed five out of thirty-two staff files (S1-S5), please refer to Confidential Names List (LIC811). All the files reviewed were organized and contained all pertinent documents required per Title 22 regulations. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. Based on the facility inspection file reviews, and interviews of staff and clients, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given Administrator Nancy Galeana along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

On August 24, 2022, at, 10:45 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a required two year inspection of the facility . LPA Linley met with Nicole Hernandez, Facility Administrator and Carol Carlson Program Director. The facility was toured inside and out. The facility is a group home (Youth Homelessness Prevention) that shelters children for up to 21 days. The facility has a capacity of 6 ambulatory male and female clients, ages 11-17 years. Current census of three clients. The facility is set up as follows: There are three upstairs bedrooms which each has two twin beds with adequate dresser, desk and closet space. There are two upstairs bathrooms that are used by all the clients. There is a downstairs restroom that is used for staff and an outside guest restroom that is located next to the Therapist office. The cleaning products are stored and locked in the laundry room by the staff office. There is a staff office located next to the living room and study area. The client records are located and locked in the staff office in file cabinets. The staff files are located and locked in a file cabinet in the Administrator's Office. The medication and first-aid kit are stored in the locked medication closet in the staff office. Additional storage and file cabinets are stored in the garage which is a non-programming area. The Administrator's office is located upstairs with an attached balcony and a Therapist office which is detached from the main home. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children shares a room. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. There is sufficient linens, blankets, towels and pillows. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The garage is maintained locked and consists of an extra refrigerator, washer/dryer, cleansers/chemicals locked in cabinet and extra PPE locked in a cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored and the locked in the staff office. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items. *** There were no guns or weapons as stated by administrator. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 105 degrees and maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. The facility has a fully sufficient food supply, including a sufficient supply of fresh fruits, vegetables, can goods, meats and staples. No expired food was located in the supply. The facility has a sufficient supply of sheets, bedding and linens. There is a fireplace located in the living room and the Therapist office and it is properly screened. There are five fire extinguishers throughout the facility. There is an outside secured gated pool located in the backyard that is used for water therapy and recreational use. Staff are in the process of taking Water Safety Certification courses through the Red Cross. The facility staff use their own vehicles to transport clients and the facility leased van. LPA completed the inspection of ten of twenty staff files (S1-S10) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 08/24/2022) three of three staff were interviewed (S5, S11, S12). LPA completed the inspection of three of three client files and three clients (C1-C3) were interviewed. During the inspection and file review, no further deficiencies were observed. Exit interview conducted, copy of LIC 809 report was provided. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of the report will be emailed to the Administrator. A copy of the report will be placed in the facility file.

Confidential interviews revealed that the sexual interaction between C1 and C2 was consensual. Confidential interviews also revealed that staff checked on C1 and C2 10-20 times throughout the course of the evenings due to C1 and C2 not immediately falling asleep at 9pm. Confidential interviews resulted in conflicting statements as to whether or not the sexual interaction between C1 and C2 was consensual or not. Based on confidential interviews, and records reviewed, the allegation that C1 was sexually assaulted by C2 while in care is unsubstantiated. Meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with the appeal rights were explained to Administrator Nicole Hernandez. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Administrator Nicole Hernandez.

An unannounced 2-year required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tana Kinder and Stephanie Lor on 12/01/2021 at 11am. LPA Kinder confirmed prior to the inspection that no staff or clients were experiencing health symptoms related to Covid19. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. There are 31 people associated to the license. The licensing fees are current. Community Care Licensing file, unusual incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to inspecting the facility. The licensing fees are current. The Youth Homelessness Prevention Center is licensed for 6 youth and has 1 youth currently placed. There are 10 staff members currently working at the facility. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files. Files reviewed were not complete and up to date with current documentation. Staff files reviewed have required education, and but were missing current CPR training cards, fingerprint clearance and CDLs. 1 random child file was also reviewed. Documentation included emergency contact information, date of placement and personal rights. The chart was complete. The facility was inspected jointly with LPAs and program manager, Lornetta Brown. A copy of the license, personal rights and emergency exit plan are prominently posted. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets, located in the office. There are 3 bedrooms with 2 beds in each bedroom. Each client is provided with a bed, dresser space, closet space and a nightstand. There are 2 bathrooms. There is a hall closet with additional linen if needed for the bedroom and the bathroom. The kitchen was accessible by the clients. met_with: Miren Hower (Chief Executive Officer), Lornetta Brown (Facility Administrator)
narrative: On 01/10/2025 at approximately 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an in-person Informal Meeting with the above facility for the purposes of discussing compliance and regulations. Present during the meeting were LPA Sarina Buchannan, LPM Rosa Rodriguez, Chief Executive Officer Miren Hower, and Facility Administrator/Facility Manager Lornetta Brown. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the licensees: Program Statement - LPA and LPM reviewed the LIC 9106 to discuss updates needed. Licensee stated they will update necessary sections of the LIC 9105 and Program Statement to reflect current program and population. Licensee stated they will begin the review and submit the updated Program Statement and LIC 9106 to the department by 4/15/25. LPA and LPM will review the new Program Statement to determine if the new revisions are in compliance with the department regulations. Client Population Served - LPA and LPM informed facility that the fire clearance granted on 11/28/26 states the clearance was granted for 6 ambulatory residents only. Facility will update their program statement to reflect correct client population served. Guardian Roster - Licensee stated that they do not have access to Guardian since being released from their contract with GoodWill and are therefore unable to associate or disassociate staff. Licensee stated they are going to either request new access or, if possible, will create a new Guardian profile if necessary. Licensee also stated they will attend the next Guardian Webinar for providers to gain knowledge on how to use and access Guardian. (report continued on LIC 812C) 4. Reporting Requirements - Licensee stated that they have not submitted any Unusual/Incident Reports for the entire year 2024 due to there being no circumstances that warranted them. LPA reminded Licensee that Medications errors were not being reported and needed to be. Licensee stated they will now be submitting Incident Reports for medications. LPA and LPM also reviewed the Reporting Requirements with Licensees and they understood the reporting timeline and the behaviors and situations that need to be reported to the department. LPA discussed the Incident report submitted to LPA Buchannan on 12/11/24. Licensee stated they will submit their 7 day report by 1/13/25 and will now submit all incidents to the LPA of the day instead of LPA Buchannan. All reports will now be submitted to CCLSacchicoincidents@dss.ca.gov. 5. Physical Plant - Licensee informed LPA and LPM that their previous maintenance person was contracted through GoodWill and the facility had been having difficulty finding a new maintenance person. Licensee stated they have now hired a maintenance person and have also created a binder that will contains all work order requests and completions. 6. Human Resources - Licensee stated that their Human Resources department was being ran by GoodWill. Licensee stated that when their GoodWill contract ended they did not give the facility personnel and client files. Licensee shared that they have had issues with locating files, finances, and all Human Resource documents needed. Facility stated they are in the process of transferring all personnel files to a virtual version but will be working on organizing physical versions of client files. 7. Pending and Cleared Citations - LPA and LPM reviewed the pending and cleared citations with Licensee. Licensee received Hour initial training's for staff dated 12/9/24, 12/26/24,1/2/25, and another training was completed on 1/2/25. Facility also provided staff training's on Client Personal Resource Log. Licensee stated they will use CCLs Personal Resource Log for the future to ensure clients sign in and out their property. Licensee also stated they will provide a signed Copy of their board minutes to LPA by 1/13/25. Additionally, Licensee informed LPA Buchannan via text on 1/7/24 that the window screens will be delivered on 1/15/25 but will still need additional time to be installed. LPA Buchannan and LPM Rodriguez offered up the opportunity for discussion and questions and Licensees did not have any more to add. LPA and LPM informed Licensee they will be referring them for the Technical Support Program (TSP) and Licensee were in agreement to get the referral to TSP. LPA stated they will follow up regarding additional resources and Technical Support Program. LPA and LPM thanked Licensees for their time and concluded the Informal Meeting.

On 12/4/2024 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan and Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPAs met with Elisa Sharrock, Shelter Support Staff and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. The facility serves up to 6 ambulatory female and male homeless or runaway clients between the ages of 12-18 years old, placed privately. Clients average length of stay is up to 18 months. Physical Plant Room 1 is a visit and activities room that has 1 couch, 2 chairs, a television, and a Playstation. Room 1 also has a closet that is used for storing donation items. Room 2 is a dining room that has a table with ample seating, a couch, and board games such as Connect 4 and Jenga. Room 3 is a staff office with a monitor that shows a live stream of facility cameras in the home, all cleaning supplies are locked in the closet, sharps are stored in filing cabinet, client medications stored in the filing cabinet, and client files. Room 4 is the kitchen with a working stove, a food pantry, a combination refrigerator and freezer, and a staff only stand up freezer. Room 5 is the laundry room with a washer, dryer, mops, the facilities water heater, and a lock ensures that the room is inaccessible to clients. Room 6 is the client bedroom with 2 dressers, 2 twin XL beds, and 2 caddies for toiletries. Room 7 is a bathroom with a working toilet and a trash can with a lid. Room 8 is a bathroom with a working toilet, a trash can with a lid, and a paper towel dispenser. Room 9 is a client bedroom with 2 dressers, 2 twin XL beds, and an exit to the backyard. Room 10 is a client bedroom with 2 dressers, 2 twin XL beds, and a closet with a door. In the hallway is a linen closet with extra sheets and blankets. The 2 client bathrooms are located in the hallway and have water temperatures of above 125 degrees Fahrenheit. There were signs posted that informed clients of the water temperature in each bathroom. The backyard is gated, with 2 hammocks, 2 tables, and a shed. The backyard is clear of debris and clean. There are 9 total cameras at the facility grounds in the following locations: 2 pointed at the driveway, 2 pointed at the front porch, 2 in the backyard, 1 in the staff office, 1 in the activity room, 1 in the dining room. (continued on LIC 809C)(Page 1) The following required documents were posted, License and Personal Rights. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible to children in care. Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees Fahrenheit. Nonperishable foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Menu present and posted in the kitchen area on the fridge. A working telephone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit is fully stocked. No Medication at the facility due to no clients being in care, medication logs were kept and stored in the office. A Fire Extinguisher is up to date and in working order. Toilets, wash basin, and bathtub are in good repair. Soap and Paper towels are available to clients. The facility is free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, and Emergency Interventions. CARE tool found the client and staffing file domains to be not applicable but LPAs Buchannan and Shulz conducted client file reviews of clients no longer in care. LPAs reviewed a total of 5 client files. LPAs were unable to conduct staff file reviews due to Administrators not being present and facility staff not having access to them. LPA also conducted 1 staff interview and no concerns for follow up were noticed. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility fees and all the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Upon inspection and file review the following deficiencies were observed: A large crack in the Window in a client bedroom (Room 10) - LPAs observed glass company to arrive at 4: PM on 12/4/24 and provided a repair estimate of 7 days. A missing air conditioning vent cover in a client bedroom. (Room 6) A hole in the door in the client bedroom. (Room 6) An electrical outlet behind the headboard of bed is missing a cover exposing the inside of the socket in the clients bedroom. (Room 9) Both window screens are bent and/or ripped in the staff office with items that need to be inaccessible to clients. Windows screen being bent allows access into staff office from the front and backyard. (Room 3) A missing shower head making the shower inoperable in 1 client bathroom. (Room 7) There is buildup of debris on the air vent in the hallway that needs to be cleaned and/or replaced. There are 3 planks on the outdoor fence which are falling off exposing the roadway. (Continued on LIC 809C) (Page 2) The facility is not having youth sign and date their personal property/resource logs upon discharge making it not possible to verify if clients are receiving their belongings upon exiting. LPAs were unable to review monthly client roster reports and board minutes due to there being no authorized employee to give LPAs access. There were no records of staff emergency disaster drills being conducted since 6/8/2021. The facility is being cited during todays inspection see (LIC 809D) and (LIC 9102TV). A follow up inspection will be conducted at a later date to conduct staff and client file reviews. An exit interview was conducted with Elisa Sharrock and a copy of this report was emailed on 12/5/24. Appeal Rights were provided during inspection. (Page 3)

On December 12, 2024 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sarina Buchannan and Tatyana Shulz made an unannounced visit with the purpose of continuing the annual inspection to the above facility using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool. LPAs met with Lornetta Brown, Facility Administrator and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. The facility serves up to 6 ambulatory female and male homeless or runaway clients between the ages of 12-18 years old, placed privately. Although the program statement states the length of stay is up to 18 months, facility confirmed clients stay a maximum of 21 days. As of today, the census is 2. On December 4, LPAs Buchannan and Shulz began the annual inspection using the CARE tool and the following domains were reviewed and completed: Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, and Emergency Interventions. CARE tool found the client and staffing file domains to be not applicable but LPAs Buchannan and Shulz conducted client file reviews of clients no longer in care. LPAs reviewed a total of 5 client files. LPAs were unable to conduct staff file reviews due to Administrators not being present and facility staff not having access to them. During today's inspection LPAs Buchannan and Shulz reviewed the following domains: Client records and staffing. LPAs reviewed 2 client record and 5 staff records. LPA conducted 1 staff interview and 1 client interview during todays inspection. Upon staff record review LPAs noticed the following deficiencies: 2 staff files are missing their tuberculosis screenings All staff files are missing the required initial 24 hour training log 4 staff files had CPR and First Aid that expired in 2023 Staff file was missing their signed job description (Report continued on LIC 809C) LPA's also observed that the vent in the hallway has been cleaned and no longer has a build up of debris. The shower head in the client bathroom was also replaced while LPAs were present. LPAs were provided a monthly written report for the month of November 2024. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Lornetta Brown, Facility Administrator.

met_with: Lorentta Brown, Facility Administrator, Chief Executive Officer Miren Hower
narrative: On 07/01/2025 at approximately 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted an in-person office meeting to go over updated required revisions of the program statement. Present during the meeting were LPA Sarina Buchannan, Chief Executive Officer Miren Hower, and Program Administrator/Facility Manager Lornetta Brown. Below is a summary of the topics that were discussed and the answers that were provided by the licensees: A Documents - LPA reviewed information that was missing in the LIC 215, LIC 500, LIC 401, LIC 503, LIC 610C, and LIC 999. LPA confirmed that Licensee will update the forms and add the LIC 401A, LIC 403, and LIC 404. Section 3 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and they explained how they will monitor educational progress. Licensee will update this section to include this. Section 5 - LPA reviewed this section with the Licensee and they explained their special services/programs and how they will be offered. Licensee will update this section to include this. Section 6 - LPA reviewed this section with the Licensee and they discussed they will remove acronyms and maintain record for 3 years instead of 1 year. Licensee will also specify which staff will help with the medication dispensing and destroying. Section 7 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee who stated they will clarify who can transport clients as well as what activities they will be transported to. They will also indicate staff cannot use their personal vehicles. (report continued on LIC 809C) Section 8 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and discussed the violations of Title 22. Licensee will remove, update, and modify this section in order to meet regulations. Licensee will make this section more clear and concise by explaining intake and intake procedures in further detail. Section 10- LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and discussed that they do not have the required information on emergency removal. Licensee will update this section. Section 12 - LPA reviewed section with Licensee and discussed violations of Title 22. LPA also discussed inconsistencies from Section 8. Section 13 to 15 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and discussed adding more detail to this section. Licensee will define "out of control" behavior. Section 18 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and discussed how there are inconsistencies from section 8 of program statement. Licensee will update this section. Section 19 - LPA reviewed this section with Licensee and discussed inconsistencies from section 8 of program statement. Licensee will update this section. Section 21 - Licensee will add names and classifications to this section. Section 22 - Licensee will provide resumes and add how long Program Administrator will be on cite. Section 23 - Licensee will ensure qualifications and duties are accurate and added to all job descriptions. Section 24 - LPA reviewed section with Licensee and discussed the list of annual training topics and requirements that were missing. Licensee will review regulations and add missing required training topics. Section 25 - Licensee will add an organizational chart. Section 28 - Licensee will update with a copy of the Facility Sketch. LPA Buchannan offered up the opportunity for discussion and questions and Licensees did not have any more to add. LPA requested that the facility make the required revisions and review their program statement and Licensee will resubmit a hard copy to the department and will not remove original copies. LPA and Licensee agreed that revisions will be submitted on 09/30/2025 and if they are unable to complete them by this time, Licensee will request and extension from LPA Buchannan via email at sarina.buchannan@dss.ca.gov. LPA thanked Licensees for their time and concluded the Office meeting.
